awd_titl_txt: Manufacturing USA: GOALI: Designing Catalytic Membrane Reactors (CMRs) for Low Temperature CO2 Utilization and Methane Dry Reforming
awd_abstract_narration:
With continued reliance on fossil fuels for most electricity production and increasing concerns about carbon dioxide emissions, carbon dioxide utilization for syngas production via dry reforming of methane (which is abundant in the U.S.) has become a very attractive possibility. The objectives of the proposed project are to design high performance catalytic membrane reactors (CMRs) for low temperature dry reforming of methane (DRM) using processible polymer-based membranes, and to build understanding of the effects of selective hydrogen removal on carbon dioxide conversion, carbon deposition and catalytic activity in this process. This GOALI project will be supported by a key industry partner (Gas Technology Institute, GTI), with one graduate student serving as an intern at GTI to evaluate the CMRs in an industrial setting. This project directly addresses a focus area of the DOE-funded Rapid Advancement in Process Intensification Deployment (RAPID) Institute through process intensification for energy-efficient manufacturing.

The proposed research plan aims to design, prepare and characterize coke resistant catalysts with high activity at low temperatures, and mixed matrix materials (MMMs) containing Pd nanomaterials in polybenzimidazole (PBI) with superior H2/CO2 separation performance. The catalysts will be subsequently integrated in CMRs and tested at laboratory scale. Models will be developed to describe the effects of selective H2 removal on the DRM reaction. The proposed work is novel in three key respects: (1) Design and preparation of nano-catalysts for DRM with improved low-temperature activity and resistance to coking using a unique flame-based aerosol process; (2) development of CMRs for low-temperature DRM using thermally stable, processible polymer-based membranes, and (3) understanding of the effect of H2-selective removal on the DRM reaction at low temperatures (including CO2 conversion, carbon deposition and catalytic activity).  CMRs based on hollow fibers will be prepared and thoroughly characterized for the DRM reaction; predictive models will be developed to uncover the effect of material and operating parameters on CO2 conversion; catalysts will be optimized for low temperature hydrogen-poor conditions; and preliminary techno-economic analysis will be performed, leading to a fuller understanding of the potential of CMRs for the DRM reaction. The graduate and undergraduate students participating in this program will be exposed to interdisciplinary research of reaction engineering, separation and materials science. The results will be incorporated into courses at the University at Buffalo, a popular textbook, and user-friendly teaching modules. Outreach activities will provide access to educational modules and research training to high school and undergraduate students from underrepresented groups in the Buffalo area and inspire them to pursue STEM careers.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
The goal of this research project was to advance the development of catalytic membrane reactors for the dry reforming of methane. Dry reforming of methane combines the two most important greenhouse gases, carbon dioxide (CO2) and methane (CH4), to produce a mixture of hydrogen (H2) and carbon monoxide (CO). This product mixture, known as synthesis gas, is a feedstock that can be used to produce fuels and chemicals. The two key activities of the project were (1) development of improved catalysts for this reaction, particularly with respect to stability and cost-effectiveness; and (2) development of improved membranes that can selectively remove the hydrogen product of the dry reforming reaction, so produce H2 and CO in separate streams. Removing H2 from streams containing CO, CO2, CH4 and H2O also has other important applications in carbon dioxide capture, utilization, and sequestration. In the context of dry reforming of methane, removal of the H2 product would shift the reaction equilibrium toward the products, allowing more of this exothermic, equilibrium-limited reaction to occur at a given temperature.

Intellectual Merit: This project produced breakthroughs in both catalyst synthesis and membrane fabrication that will have broad scientific and technological impact. In the area of catalyst synthesis, a new approach to producing supported-metal catalysts in a single step using a scalable and economical flame-based aerosol reactor was developed. This produced dry reforming catalysts with exceptional performance and stability, and can also be used much more broadly. Two new mechanisms of catalyst production were revealed: (1) formation of active sites by exsolution of metal nanoclusters from metastable amorphous solid solution nanospheres, and (2) production of metal-loaded mesoporous silica hollow nanospheres in a single step by surfactant templating in a flame-driven reactor. In the area of membranes for hydrogen separation, this project produced two new approaches as well: (1) plasma treatment of silicon-containing polymer membranes to produce an ultra-thin silica-like selective layer, and (2) development of carbon molecular sieves with hourglass-shaped pore structures. Both of these produced unprecedented performance in the selective permeation of H2 relative to CO2 and other gases. Each of these breakthroughs will have scientific impact far beyond the specific use case of dry reforming of methane. They have been published, or will be published, in about a dozen refereed journal publications that will reach a broad scientific audience and have also been presented at numerous technical conferences and seminars.

Broader Impacts: The technological broader impacts of this project arise from its potential contribution to climate change mitigation. Combining methane from abundant, low-cost natural gas reserves with captured CO2 to create new chemical feedstocks, ultimately for production of durable chemicals, provides a carbon-neutral or carbon-negative route to responsible utilization of natural gas resources. The educational broader impacts of this work include the training of 4 Ph.D. students, 8 M.S. students and two undergraduate researchers over the course of the project. It provided them with experience in a cutting-edge collaboration across three research groups that exposed them to multiple scientific perspectives and advising styles. Work on this project prepared them for careers that address issues of energy and climate change from a chemical engineering perspective.


Last Modified: 03/06/2022
Modified by: Mark T Swihart
